Class ReadFile

  • java.lang.Object
    • ReadFile

  • public class ReadFile
extends java.lang.Object
    This class will read Java files and then determine whether braces are balanced, files are identical, and will allow the user to write a Mad Libs story.
    Author:
    annemariecaballero

      ReadFile​()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main​(java.lang.String[] args)

      • readAndCheck

        public static void readAndCheck​(java.lang.String[] files)
        Loads the files and performs the three main functionalities: 1. Checking if a file has balanced braces 2. Checking if two files are identical 3. Filling in provided spots in a story
        Parameters:
        files - a String[] that holds the names of all the files to be used

      • loadFile

        public static java.lang.StringBuffer loadFile​(java.lang.String pathname)
                                       throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
        This method reads a file by character using BufferedReader. Returns the file's contents as a StringBuffer. This method was taken (almost completely the same) from pg.415 of the Java Methods book by Maria and Gary Litvin.
        Parameters:
        pathname - the name of the file to read
        Returns:
        a StringBuffer with the contents of the file
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - occurs if the file, with name pathname, cannot be found

      • bracesBalanced

        public static boolean bracesBalanced​(java.lang.StringBuffer strB)
        Checks a StringBuffer object to see if all open braces within the StringBuffer have an accompanying closing curly brace.
        Parameters:
        strB - the StringBuffer for whose curly brace pairs are to be checked
        Returns:
        true, if the curly braces, if any, are all in pairs; false, otherwise.

      • fillInStory

        public static java.lang.StringBuffer fillInStory​(java.lang.StringBuffer strBuffer,
                                                 java.lang.StringBuffer strBuffer2)
        Returns a StringBuffer that has the original story with all the phrases surrounded by <> as well as the <> removed. The returned StringBuffer will either be filled with user response or with words from an already-provided file.
        Parameters:
        strBuffer - the name of the first file, which contains the story, with parts to be filled in
        strBuffer2 - a list of words to use to fill in the areas between <> in the story. if there is no already-provided file where this list came from this will be equal to "".
        Returns:
        a StringBuffer that has the original story but with the new words filled in in place of the <> and phrases between them.
